title: When will the 7-day average of new COVID-19 cases in the UK next fall below 15,000?
preds: for cases to fall below 15k, past
It is already December 7, the trend is up, but there have been some steep declines in the past hence 2% for before dec 18
Based on current trends I don’t see any path to 15000 by 12/17.
Even if cases start to drop rapidly at this point with 4 weeks to go to closing we'd need an incredibly fast rate of decline to have it reach below 15,000 in the 7 day average.

The case numbers and the hospitalization numbers remain stable. I don't expect them to go up significantly (no new variant on the horizon, the booster shot adoption is steady), so I don't expect the government to add new restrictions that would curve down significantly the number of cases.
Heading back up and looking increasingly unlikely before December 18.

I thought there was a good chance UK would hit a certain amount of herd immunity before the end of 2021, even with the delta plus variant, but it looks like this is becoming less and less of a possibility
Still at over 35000. No sign of decline.
Cases going in the wrong direction again unfortunately
I don't think the UK Government is remotely interested in lowering case numbers that far. It seems to have decided about 40,000 a day is optimal.

Yesterdays update was overconfident as I didn't consider that there would be more than one lag in the system before cases would start to be detected again following the half term break. I think we will only see the true direction of travel in cases by the end of this week.
Adjusting up to 3% now they're down to 34,000.

Cases falling at around 15% week on week at the moment. 12% needed going forward to get below 15,000 by that date. Cases dropping more rapidly now, even though schools are back. Dropping in school age children and in the age bracket of their parents. I think the biggest risk is an increase in the 20-35 bracket cancelling some of that decrease out.

Case numbers in England are starting to fall, even allowing for the half-term break and potential for reduced testing. 
I'm expecting a plateau and slight increase over next two weeks, but it may end up close between bin3 and 4 if numbers keep dropping.

There's currently very little being done to control Coronavirus in the UK, and the time left on this question is short, so I'm not optimistic.
(1) Policy doesn't change (60%).  I see no reason to expect a sudden fall in cases (a gradual reduction due to increasing natural + vax immunity in the population is plausible, but insufficient).
(2) Some restrictions (36%).  But light restrictions are unlikely to get us down to 15K by 18th December.  This 'half assed' approach, doing just enough to keep the hospitals from overflowing into the streets, is consistent with previous Conservative behaviour.
(3) Hard restrictions introduced by 27th November (4%).  Based on the last wave, we might need about 3 weeks of this to get down from 40K to 15K (I acknowledge many variables have changed since then).

Adjusting bin 3 slightly upwards as cases are decreasing for now. Cases may continue to stay above 15,000 for a while because of the large amount of testing in the UK, but I do think that there will soon be a point where most of the population has enough immunity for there to be a meaningful decline in cases.

See my comments here https://www.gjopen.com/comments/1347009
High testing rates in the UK will keep reported cases high.
Cases are getting worse but there'll be no appetite to act while the death and hospitalisation curves remain flat.
Yet another bad day. I'll be at 100% if two of the next three are also bad.
Very nearly at 50,000 per day again with no real appetite for turning it around.
Cases rate is rising, which was unexpected.
No changes in policy. Less people wearing masks and using sanitiser. Just spent some time in London, only about one third of people wearing masks on the tube. No change in schools.
Colder weather increasing risk of indoor transmission.

A lot of cases, a lot of testing finding cases even if not severe.  Also a lot of non COVID coughs and colds.
Given there are high rates of cases with high rates of vaccination, meaning vaccinated people are getting COVID, as well as the fact that life is largely back to normal and it’s now autumn in the northern hemisphere and the theory that COVID is a winter virus and finally that cases have been steady around 30k ish for the past 2 months, all lead to the likelihood of cases dropping off before December being quite low.  After all it’s only 8 weeks to mid December.
Hedging toward the crowd, though I'm not convinced it will sustain for so long. Other countries have seen pretty significant fluctuations, and December 17th is more than two months from now.
No longer enough time to drop to 15000 by the end of the month.
Has not happened since May 2021 and just a few times before that. I guess that april 2022 is more relevant.
Given the cases going around it seems pretty impossible to drop off so much by the end of Oct which is 4 weeks away.

Covid cases in uk have consistently been running at >15k cases since 28th june. Ever since april 21 full lockdown restrictions have eased as cases fell and vax rates increased. Approaching now almost 70% vax rate and further restrictions easing on large venues and international travel don't see high likelihood of cases coming down unless strict lockdown rules being put in place which would require significantly higher ratea of infection vs now and politically very unlikely due to governments insistence against lockdown b

The late rollout of vaccination of 12-15-year-olds combined with the winter months, and compounded by the flu season, makes for a rather grim confluence of issues. This could be averted if the uptake of vaccination of 12-15 is very successful. Additional mitigation in schools would also help.
Cases are still heading back up. The only time the UK has reduced cases from 35000 to 15000 it took 20 days and that was with restrictions.

Schools are still in with very little mitigations in place. It’s getting colder so more social meet-ups will be indoors. Gigs and large crowd events are going ahead. Govt in England ditched vaccine passports idea. I don’t anticipate measures changing at governmental level.
Winter is in general likely to lead to an increase in respiratory diseases, and although there is limited historical context, this has also proven to be the case for COVID-19.
Heading back up and more sharply than last time.
The rate is going up again, so dropping the chance of it reaching 15K in October.
The rate seems to be rising again. So this may not happen in October. Not sure what is driving a reversal.
Two more weeks at the pace of decline it underwent in the past week would put it right at 15k. Going up on prior to October 29 for now, though I'm not sure this pace can be sustained.

We've dropped below 26K twice. The first time it kept going down, the second time it went back up. The first time we had many restrictions. The second time we had very few. I' surprised the current downward trend is happening at all. It might continue, but I think it more likely that it won't.

https://www.independent.co.uk/news/covid-news-live-announcement-today-uk-b1919645.html
at the moment cases are starting to trend down again (5 days of downward trend). 
school has started again and its been 2 weeks since most started so any rise as a result of school starting should be coming through now.
PM has just announced if things get out of hand restrictions be brought in. if restrictions occur it could bring numbers down quicker.
Updating for downward trend past 7 days
Hope wrong, just can't see a way where breakthrough cases going to reduce quickly. Feels too close to home maybe, driving pessimism.
11 Sep is tomorrow, the others are mainly just conservative guesswork

I'm still saying that case numbers will slowly keep rising through September. Vaccination levels are increasing in the teens and early 20's age groups, so this will help slow transmission and symptomatic cases, but won't stop the spread for some time yet.  
There is a small chance of a 'fire-break' over half-term in October, which would quickly lower numbers, but I doubt this will happen given the Governments past performance. Having said that, the clearest sign that any restriction will come to pass is when the UK Gov says it definitely won't, and vice versa. So 35% on bin3 looks about right for now.
May achieve a dip before the full effects of school return and colder months impact.

Case numbers still rising, heading into winter, waning vaccine efficacy, ideological resistance to mitigation, and most importantly a strong civil service to prevent the government publishing falsehoods. Actually a 16% chance of less than 15,000 cases a day before 18/12 seems optimistic.

The case rate will come down one way or the other, either due to vaccinations of people recovering with some immunity. The rate is still rising for now, so October 29 is less likely than it was. I’m am watching for the rate to start to fall.

I currently see no reason why rates would fall by more than half from the current level (c. 41k as of 6th Sep 2021). With schools returning and the weather turning I would assume the next significant move - if any - is up. I assume behaviour is now fairly stable, I can't see people collectively taking voluntary action that leads to a massive drop, neither can I see a rationale for the government to impose more stringent rules. They have made big play about the vaccines breaking-the-link-etc-etc and there is little in the hospitalisation or deaths data to suggest they would need to enforce anything significant (ratios of hosp/deaths to cases is way down on January). I will confess an element of wishcasting here, as I am prone to do. A wildcard might be a massive deadly wave of normal influenza given that flu rates have collapsed recently so we are now all freshly-vulnerable. It is possible that there would be a lockdown for THAT which would indirectly lead to a big fall in covid rates. Hopefully not though!

The highest rate of cases tends to be in the younger age groups, particularly between 15-25yrs, which are less vaccinated and more likely to meet socially and through schools/higher education. I still see cases rising slowly through September as new terms start, leaving little time for a substantial drop before November.
Updated for passage of time, as rates don't deem to be falling, schools due to come back, and I can;t see any other dramatic intervention which will reduce cases anytime soon

The ceiling of vaccine immunity must be nearing its peak, and it is hard to see what else could start to drive cases down other than a substantial level of herd immunity, which is a long way and may be unattainable.

Updating a previous forecast (https://www.gjopen.com/comments/1323447).
It seems clear now that cases will not fall below a 7 day average of 15,000 by September 11. The reopening of schools and the arrival of autumn still makes it very unlikely that cases will fall below 15,000 by October. Restrictions being reintroduced could cause a fall in cases but they would need to be introduced fairly soon to have time to take effect before the end of October. If restrictions are reintroduced, perhaps some time in October following a rise in cases in September, it does seem possible that cases will fall below an average of 15,000 between November and mid-December. Nonetheless, this depends on restrictions being reintroduced, which may only happen if hospital cases keep increasing despite increased vaccination rates and the possibility of booster shots (especially for the elderly). Politically, the government may be keen on introducing restrictions in time for them to take effect before Christmas in order to avoid the risk of repeating the fiasco of Christmas 2019. This analysis also assumes that the number of tests carried out does not decrease substantially, which would obfuscate the real number of cases.
7-day average still climbing. Not enough time for a drop to 15,000 based on previous drop rates.
It went up further today, so I think a drop by September 11 is very unlikely
Cases are going to stay steady and high for a good while now that everyone is mixing again.  Can’t see it dropping off quickly.

The first 2 periods with 7-day average cases above 15000 cases lasted 6 weeks to 2 months respectively. 
Since end of June 7-day average cases are above 15000 with again an increasing trend. General view is not to repeat a lockdown as has been implemented before. 
47 million people received 1 dose while 41 million people received 2 doses of vaccinations. 
UK population is 68 million people of which +/- 14 million are aged below 18 taking still as an assumption this age group account for 2% of infections (source March 2021 https://post.parliament.uk/latest-evidence-on-impacts-of-covid-19-in-children-march-2021/). This leaves 6 million people not being vaccinated 
Therefore I expect quite a slow decline.

updating a previous forecast (https://www.gjopen.com/comments/1316926).
Since the number of cases has started going back and the positivity rate has been stable around 4% (with the number of daily tests also being stable), it seems less likely that there will be a fall in cases in time for the 11th of September milestone, especially with the upcoming bank holiday and people returning from holiday abroad (which lead to an increase in cases last year as people caught covid in France, where cases started rising earlier, before coming back to the UK).
As before, if cases are not below 15,000 by the 11th of September it is unlikely that they will be below 15,000 until after the 18th of December because of schools (which previously lead to an increase in cases) and universities (for the first time since March 2020) reopening, as well as the winter generally favouring scenarios with a high number of cases. Because cases may be driven primarily by younger people (school children and university students), booster shots for the elderly and most vulnerable may not be effective at reducing the number of cases (although they should reduce the death rate among those with boosters).
7 day rate still rising. Chance of a turnaround in the next few days is now very small.

It seems impossible that numbers will decrease that much until 11 September. I do not understand why crowd forecast gives "Between 11 September 2021 and 29 October 2021" a chance of 51%. Vaccination rate will not rise that fast and I do not believe in another lockdown. This would be the only realistic chance that numbers would decline during that time. The summer is over than, schools are full and many events will be inside. I give it 20% and this seems to be quite optimistic to me.
Cases are still rising. Just barely enough time to drop by 9/11.
Trending the first bin down because of the drastic rate down [relative to my previous forecasts] needed to get there.

Reverting to previous forecast. Case numbers look likely to rise gently again through September due to greater social interaction among <25yrs as schools as unis restart. The level of vaccination rapidly drops off around this age, and therefore will keep transmission and cases from dropping quickly before end of October, when the half-term holidays could tip the balance.
Dropped to 26,000. It might keep dropping.
Reducing probability for before Sept 11, now that cases have stabilized (or are in a slight growth). Evenly distributed with the rest of the possibilities to hedge.
Schools go back in Scotland this week, England in a few weeks. Kids still not vaccinated.

Going back to my original forecast, for the reasons I have originally explained.
I've made a mistake by taking too much into account short term changes that I can't explain.
Readjusting to consider that the faster cases go up, the quicker they come down (India). Its opposite is a slow and steady increase and decline like Brazil.
Hovering at ~30k, and end of August schools will start again (meaningend of holidays, returning holiday makers, more interaction among citizens)

It’s not dropping right now. The last time there was a sustained decline, it took about 18 days to drop from around 28K per day to 15K per day. We could still get there if it started a sustained drop in the next few days, but that doesn’t look likely.
If it hasn't fallen below the threshold by the end of the school holidays, it is unlikely to do so before 2022, possibly next spring.

Cases went up again, so it’s looking less likely they will drop below 15K before September 11. From here we need about 15% per week decline—rates we’ve seen before, but that hasn’t resumed. Something is driving an increase for now.
Tweaking to favor bin 2 as UK cases appear to be holding steady. Lots of uncertainty in my opinion, could go up or down from here, or just plateau a while.
Case numbers are getting less likely to drop quickly from here; numbers may flatten and start to decline but I expect another increase during September.
With the EPL starting in 2 days, chances of a drop look slimmer now so coming down
We not up again today, it’s not clear what is happening. In any event, dropping to 15,000 cases looks less likely than before.

It's a tough one between before/after 11 September, but I think it's likely we'll see delayed effects of increased freedom - people slowly going back to offices, people starting to travel abroad more, people tiring of track & trace efforts - which will slow any further decrease in numbers. Google mobility data suggests we could still get a lot closer to 'normal' levels of movement, with all the added risk of infection that entails.  Vaccination rates appear to be tailing off a bit, and while vaxes now extended to 16+ I'm not sure that'll work quickly enough to hit 11 September.  School returners give me some concern we might not even hit 29 October, but (barring new variants) maintaining 15k+ consistently for 4 over months (21 June - 29 October) suggests herd immunity ain't really a thing. https://www.gstatic.com/covid19/mobility/2021-08-06_GB_Mobility_Report_en-GB.pdf Edit: Centre for Cities also suggests there's room for more mobility esp. people coming back to office https://www.centreforcities.org/blog/did-freedom-day-boost-the-high-street-recovery/

Avg Daily cases have gone up today at 25,161, which is +3,209 vs Last week , if they keep on plateauing at this level until school start it will take even more time to come down School start, and holiday end will be another inflection point of major sources of contact in an open, unrestricted context
Cases are continuing to plateau or gently rise. Reducing confidence in the next month. Thanks to @paulm for the discussion on this.

7 day average in the decline in daily new cases has dropped to -1.35%, which is still a decline but now projects to around Sept 15-16 for crossing 15k in the 7 day average. I'm not sure yet what the jump in new cases on Aug 5 and 6 indicates. Thus, decreasing my probability for before Sept 11, and increasing it for the other three options (mostly towards Sept 11-Oct 29 option).
Cases rose a bit today. Adjusting after Sep 11 percentage a bit more.

It was dropping about 20% per week, but it's been going up for the past two days.  With 5 weeks, to go, it must go down about 11% per week to reach 15,000, so there still time for this to reach 15,000 by September 11th.  The trend has only been broken for two days, so I'll be looking at this until a new trend is established.  Covid is really hard to predict.

Looks like the recent decline has stopped and is reversing a bit so reducing confidence in before September 11. However new per day cases appear pretty noisy so it'll be interesting to see what the trend looks like after another week. I still think it can drop fairly quickly as seen in other countries but I'm less confident it will drop quickly. https://ourworldindata.org/explorers/coronavirus-data-explorer?zoomToSelection=true&time=2020-08-25..latest&facet=none&pickerSort=asc&pickerMetric=location&Metric=Confirmed+cases&Interval=7-day+rolling+average&Relative+to+Population=false&Align+outbreaks=false&country=~GBR

I’m clearly not with the crowd on the one, and may get left out in the cold, but the likeliest option to me is an erratic, marginal descent through August before another swell in cases from mid/late September. This makes November the likeliest time for numbers to retreat back below 15,000 av. in my view. 
There is a slim chance in the window just before schools reopen so I’m hedging slightly on bin1 to avoid a brier faceplant.
I suspect the recent peak and drop may have been exaggerated due to particular circumstances; on the way up with England (and Scotland to some extent) in the Euros, plus mixed weather, leading to a lot more social mixing indoors; and then on the way down especially by the 15-20% drop in testing in the two weeks from 15th July, which was apparently skewed towards younger age groups, and related to the NHS app/isolating/holidays.

At the current rate at which the number of cases is decreasing, the UK could get to a point where the 7-day average is below 15,000 before the 11th of September. Because of holiday travels being allowed (to some extent) a certain amount of people who might test positive (e.g., young people partying) may also test positive abroad. However, this is not overwhelmingly likely given that the holiday period in the UK could also result in at least maintaining 15,000-20,000 cases a day as long as no new restrictions are introduced. If the number of cases is not below 15,000 by September 11th it is possible that it may not fall below 15,000 before November due to schools reopening, which may drive an increase in cases as Younger students may not be vaccinated. It is therefore possible that the fall below 15,000 cases may only happen after November.

Reasons for high probablity before 11 Sep:
- despite "Freedom Day" on 19 July with removal of most restrictions, new infection numbers have peaked 15 July; many people are still cautious and have not adjusted their behaviour to the relaxed rules
- mobility is still significantly below pre-COVID levels (https://www.gstatic.com/covid19/mobility/2021-07-30_GB_Mobility_Report_en-GB.pdf); workplaces and public transport 30-40% below pre-pandemic
- school holidays (except Scotland) last until end of August/beginning of September, so spread via schools should stay limited until 11 September
- the EURO 2021 (football), which seems to have driven the massive increase up to mid July, is over
- ongoing vaccination roll-out; early 30s and 20s are now getting their second jab
- 15000 is not particularly low (last time 21 June 2021), corresponds to 7-day average new infections per 100k of 159, most countries aim for 20-50 Will require frequent updating based on evolving new infection numbers.

From Nov 19-Dec 5, and from May 17-22, the UK had "red herring" type declines in infection - drops in growth rates in the midst of otherwise sustained rises. There were new new relaxed health measures put in place on July 19, and a surprising quick drop in cases following that. Test positivity has dropped and tests performed has dropped, which to me indicates fewer cases are being caught. I am guessing (without proof) that there is some sort of administrative rearrangement in the health system affecting how doctors recommend testing, and how cases get reported. While the situation may not be as rosy in reality, I do not see a reason to believe why the current decline in officially reported cases reported will continue until cases reach below 15k daily, which could happen after August 13 (based on an average decrease of 5.09% in new reported cases over the past 7 days). However, if a reason I am not aware of causes it to rebound up, I do not believe it will come back down for some time, due to the drop in temperature and gradual switch to indoors activities. So, either it crosses the 15k mark in mid-August, or we wait much much longer.

After a short period of increase, the numbers are declining again for several days in a row now. Obviously, July 19 did not have a great effect. There are 5-6 weeks until 11 September and it seems probable that the numbers will fall below 15,000 during summer time. This could be possible even in the next 1-2 weeks if the numbers continue do decline as during the last days. I think only great carelessness or holiday returnees could torpedo the declining trend.
I was expecting case numbers to flatten off but it looks like they may now descend further, and could result in bin1. Perhaps because of August holidays and pingdemic after-effects.
The trend has continued, though the underlying mechanism for this is not deeply clear

7-day rate has dropped to about 25000, and it’s still falling. Same thing happened earlier in the year in India. Data suggests the variant spreads quickly to the vulnerable, then perhaps there is no one left to infect.

https://www.theguardian.com/world/2021/aug/01/is-covid-19-on-the-run-in-the-uk-fall-case-numbers-herd-immunity
case dropping but slight increase over the last few days. question only asks for numbers to drop below 15k. there is a good chance the numbers could drop that low and then spike back up once school starts.
last spike was attributed in part to football world cup, what effect is Olympics having - do people watch this at home or together?

After the rising numbers on July 28 and 29 I thought that this would be a trend reversal due to the removal of corona restrictions on July 19. This seems to be the case, but at least the impact was not that high. The numbers are falling again. It is very difficult to have any kind of certainty at the moment, but since the numbers are slowly falling again, I revise the chances of "Before 11 September 2021" from 35% up to 45%. The next few days will give more clarity on the effect of July 19. If the numbers will not falling below 15,000 until 11 September, I suspect that it will be "Not before 18 December". Johnson will be reserved in putting restrictions back into place and when the summer is over, numbers will likely rise again.

School reopens in September and the EPL (English Premier league) starts mid August so assuming that the current declining trend sustains (we have seen the cases flatten out in the past 3 days), the 7 day average should has to hit below 15k before that date or else, expect cases to rise a bit after that.

The Uk cases continue to be high. Great weather recently has meant outdoor rather than indoor mixing. As the weather turns more wintry and schools head back the cases will continue to be high. Also, children are not vaccinated.

Not easy to gauge this one accurately as cases may be higher than currently reported; young people are avoiding getting tested due to the ‘pingdemic’ and holidays, we are barely over a week into the end of restrictions, and younger adults are far less likely to be fully vaccinated. 
Given that, and current delta prevalence, I don’t think cases will fall another 50% within six weeks, although 80% adults fully vaccinated by September should slow transmission.
And from September there will be more testing and schools return, so another increase is likely, which could push numbers back above 30k for a while.

Covid cases are on the rise again. July 24: 31.285
July 25: 28.652
July 26: 24.386
July 27: 23.228
July 28: 25.402
July 29: 30.633 Yesterday I thought this could be an outlier, but now it seems to be a clear trend reversal and a consequence of the July 19 decision to remove all restrictions. At least the rapid decline of cases is clearly stopped. I do not expect Johnson to put restrictions in place again during the next weeks since the decision was made when numbers were high and increasing. So "Before 11 September" would be a very optimistic guess in view of the current trend. Since death cases are still relatively low because of the high vaccination rate I expect Johnson to take the risk of high numbers of COVID cases.
Less use of the app and subsequent testing to avoid being ping'd

@Jprice94 @mkarbowsky @Pablo_Vargas
Cases have started to come down and the last time cases were at the level of their July peak, it took about a month to get below 15,000. I think people are going to take this seriously and work to limit the spread, the increased transmissibility of Delta notwithstanding.

Current trajectory
School holidays mean less lateral flow testing, so fewer going to PCR
Expect cases to drop them rise again in mid September
I'm involved in forecasting numbers for our area. The numbers left 'at risk' are falling quickly, if one assumes exposure offers some immunity.
Since last week uk delta and covid cases down 24% with 92% of adult population either vaxxed or antibodies, and Scotland down more, things are looking good over there.

I'm mostly with @Tom-Willerton-Gartside. A few days ago I wrote, that if the decline would continue to mirror the rise before 20 July, the 15,000 line would be crossed mid August, but I thought the rapid decline would stop. However, it did not. From 20,000 to 47,000 on 20 July it took 10 days, from 47,000 to 30,000 it took only 8 days (https://www.google.com/search?q=corona+f%C3%A4lle+vereinigtes+k%C3%B6nigreich&oq=corona+f%C3%A4lle). Now 10 days after 19 July I do not fully understand why there is no visible effect, but if there would be a significant one, it should already be visible. It seems unavoidable that the numbers will be below 15,000 already in August. Full vaccination rate is already at 55% and will continue to rise (https://ourworldindata.org/covid-vaccinations?country=GBR) and the good weather also does its part so that most people meet outside. The only unclear variable seems to be how holiday returnees might affect the situation.
Vaccination is going well with nearly 90% first dose and around 80% second dose. Both of which should help.

COVID cases rapidly falling, meaning that on current levels <15k should be met before 11/9. The only doubts on meeting this target are effect of 19/7 and 16/8 unlocking and whether government can drive up vaccine uptake in U40s. If cases rise to unsustainable levels on NHS, I think it is 90%+ likely than Johnson would reintroduce measures, which would drive down cases. I think it is likely that cases will rise in aftermath of 19/7, but cases will soon drop after in time to meet 11/9 deadline.
Narrowing on the lower the end as it looks to be declining quickly

The decline in numbers during the last days is astonishing. If it would mirror the rise before 20 July id would be mid August when 15,000 are reached. However, I expect due to the abandonment of restrictions it will not be that fast. Summer holidays could be another factor that will hinder rapid decline.

There are a lot of dynamics to consider here: Over the last week, there has been a surprisingly strong down surge in the number of COVID cases. (see: https://www.theguardian.com/world/2021/jul/26/what-is-behind-the-latest-fall-in-cases-of-covid-across-the-uk and https://www.ft.com/content/cb86d9a8-665d-467e-9b92-4b80e905060c). This is likely attributable to the UK heatwave, driving people's behavior to bed in less close contact indoors. If you assume an exponential decline in the caseload from the past 5 days, which is when the 7day MA started a downturn, we could plausibly hit under 15,000 cases on the MA by August the 3rd. This precision is not justified, but the margin for error places this well below the 11th of September. This downward trajectory seems unlikely to be sustained, especially if it's driven by the weather (we are due for bleaker times in the near future sadly: https://www.bbc.co.uk/weather/outlook). However, August is still a warm month, which could keep R below one for around a month, which given the sharpness of decline in the caseload, could result in the cases being below 15,000 by September.  This will need to be updated in light of evidence about how sustained the recent downturn is. It could be more likely if it's driven by other factors than the weather, eg school summer holidays. This could be a major factor for two reasons: 1) Students are no longer undergoing routine lateral flow tests,  so less detection of the cases load 2) Less spreading within schools.  Vaccine rollout is still suggestive that the case load could continue declining, especially with recent reports of 90% of adults having antibodies (see first Guardian article above).  Though non of these factors alone is enough to suggest that the R number remains permanently below 1 (see: https://www.thelancet.com/action/showPdf?pii=S1473-3099%2821%2900143-2), in combination, there's a reasonable likelihood that the 7 day MA could reach below 15,000 in August. I place the estimate at 50% because recently all restrictions have because R needs to be below 1 for a sustained period of time, longer than it has so far appears to have been, in order to reach this target. Given that all restrictions, and especially with the reopening of nightclubs, it seem's plausible that R would quickly return to above 1, which could occur in even a relatively well-vaccinated population. We also need to factor in possible new, vaccine-resistant variants arising (which is not implausible).  A lot of updating will need to be done when evidence for the reasons for the recent downturn becomes stronger.

Cases are falling fast. Last time They peaked at levels seen recently it took just 3 weeks for them to drop by two thirds. Best guess is that will happen again.  Will reevaluate if the trend does not continue.

Another day trending down. The 7 day average went from 38.2K on Jul 22 to 36.1K on Jul 23. 
If we were to continue linearly (yes, that's an oversimplification), it should hit 15K in August...

Rates are starting to come down to 37k from 45k only 5 days earlier.  For the first time in a long time I believe that UK rates will decline due to summer and a very high rate of infection and likely unidentified asymptomatic cases in teenagers and young workers in metropolitan areas that have likely avoided getting tested or know ways around the test e.g. orange juice vs other tricks.  The overwhelming desire to travel internationally and avoid any risk to this, will drive a reduction in specific group at a higher rate of isolation than any govt initiative could hope achieve.  These two combined will provide a net reduction in reported cases for the Sept return to school, covering the actual number which could easily be higher again post October.
High infection rate + high vaccination rate + low reinfection rate = eventually low numbers of people to infect
Big drop in numbers today. 6 weeks until 11sept so plenty of time for cases to go any which way. But makes earlier more likely.

If it followed the trajectory of the last lockdown it would drop below 15k before September 11th. I think there's a decent chance of this, especially considering the quick rise and fall of cases in India as well. The UK has a high rate of vaccinations and I think this may help cases decline quickly as well. However, leaving plenty of potential for cases to remain high for an extended period.

The decline in January was due to the lockdown. It is not probable at all that there will be another lockdown and the vaccination effect was not really visible during the last weeks. I suspect it will be, but there won't be such a rapid decline as in January. So the only reasonable chance will be "Between 11 September 2021 and 29 October 2021" (30%). After that we will all be much more inside and the chance for infections will rise again. Then it will be "not before 18 December 2021" (50%). Than the numbers might decrease faster.

Cases look to be levelling off at just under 50k per day.  It took about 1month to 6 weeks to reduce after the last wave.  However we do have to consider this was during lockdown and it is the summer holidays with limited restrictions.  We have the effects of major events like festivals and sporting events to consider, which may keep cases high. I’m going for somewhere in October for it to dip this far.  But will revise when we see how the summer goes.

There are 4 factors which could bring the number of cases down:
1. Restrictions being imposed by the government
2. Behavior changes of the population which reduce infections (such as more distancing, masks)
3. Some better and more broadly available medical solution (better vaccines, etc.)
4. "The fire running out of fuel"
I'll address these one by one.
1. Restrictions: I don't expect the government to return the restrictions. They have just lifted them on July 19, knowing the situation with the delta variant. The only reason to have restrictions is if hospitals are overwhelmed, and that is unlikely to happen given the high and increasing vaccination rates and the protection that vaccines provide against being seriously ill.
2. Behavior changes to reduce contacts: there is no incentive for the population to do so, given the the high and increasing vaccination rates and the protection that vaccines provide against being seriously ill. With the restrictions lifted, the opposite is to be expected.
3. Medicine: even if tomorrow there was a hypothetical new medication / vaccination that the whole population (including the children) could take that would prevent infections, it will take many months for everyone to take it (and again there won't be an incentive).
4. Herd immunity / running out of new people to infect. Out of the 4, this is the trickiest to estimate.
Even with the high vaccination rate, there will still be a significant % (e.g. children, but not only) who are not vaccinated. In addition, while vaccination protects against being seriously ill and fatalities, the protection against catching the disease is much lower.
Will the UK get to herd immunity? Officially, 8.38% of the population has tested positive, but some studies claim that the actual numbers are 8-10 times higher. Even so, the protection that previously being sick provides is unclear, and estimated to be less than that of vaccinations.
Falling below 15K cases / day out of a 66M population means 0.02% of the population being infected, which is not that much.
See also the modeling done here: https://covid19.healthdata.org/united-kingdom?view=infections-testing&tab=trend&test=infections
Assuming any policy intervention only takes place after the summer

It has taken about a month for cases to fall enough to get from where they are now to below 15,000. The big variable is whether cases are near their peek now. And also whether the delta variant is harder to arrest once out in the world.

The latest round of lockdowns have been lifted: https://www.ctvnews.ca/world/johnson-england-to-lift-last-virus-restrictions-on-july-19-1.5505499 I expect daily cases to start rising again shortly. Lockdowns are very effective and effective pretty quickly, but given the reluctance to engage in them, I simply don't see them returning until cases spike more dramatically. Double vaccinations are still rising in the UK, but the "at least 1 dose" group seems to be stabilizing at 70% of the population. Only about 20% of the "at least 1 dose" group are still waiting on a 2nd shot, therefore I don't expect vaccination to play a big role in subduing case numbers.
On reflection, Sept 11 is a big ask., even the amount of vaccinated people getting the virus is exceeding 15k a day currently.
January peak subsided in less than 8 weeks and think with higher vaccinations rates a repeat is perfectly possible. Vaccination not the same as immunisation of course.
